qas.question: What direction did British architecture go in mid 18th century?
What were Robert Wood's influential Greek monuments from mid 18th century?
Who began the revolution of Greek influenced architecture in Britain?
What brothers were instrumental in this Greek movement of neoclassicism?
What changed the course of British architecture starting in the mid-1800s?
What move towards a less pure form of Greco-Roman architecture during the eighteenth century?

plausible_answers.text: the majority of contemporary British architects and designers

qas.question: Who adopted a combination of complex forms and high levels of enrichment?
What revolution was begun by the Adams brothers?
Where were architects like George dance based?

context: From the middle of the 18th century, <b4_0>exploration and publication<b4_0/> changed the course of <b5_0>British architecture<b5_0/> towards a purer vision of <b7_0>the <a0_0>Ancient Greco-Roman ideal<b7_0/><a0_0/>. <a2_0>James 'Athenian' Stuart<a2_0/>'s work The Antiquities of Athens and Other Monuments of Greece was very influential in this regard, as were Robert Wood's <a1_0>Palmyra and Baalbec<a1_0/>. A combination of simple forms and high levels of enrichment was adopted by <b6_0>the majority of contemporary British architects and designers<b6_0/>. The revolution begun by Stuart was soon to be eclipsed by the work of the <a3_0>Adam Brothers<a3_0/>, James Wyatt, Sir William Chambers, George Dance, James Gandon and <b8_0>provincially based<b8_0/> architects such as John Carr and Thomas Harrison of Chester.
